Claim: Upon approval from Supreme People’s Court, China will kill 20,000 patients with novel coronavirus.
Explaination: There is no such case being tried at the Supreme People’s Court of China. The high court’s record of scheduled hearings on its official website does not show that it was set to decide on such a case on Feb. 7, and neither is there a record of it on the resolved cases tab and press releases.
Label: False
html:
Claim: Upon approval from Supreme People’s Court, China will kill 20,000 patients with novel coronavirus.

Explanation:There is no such case being tried at the Supreme People’s Court of China. The high court’s record of scheduled hearings on its official website does not show that it was set to decide on such a case on Feb. 7, and neither is there a record of it on the resolved cases tab and press releases.

https://verafiles.org/articles/vera-files-fact-check-report-claiming-china-kill-20k-covid-1

Claim: Pigs mulled in China are blamed for coronavirus.
Explaination: The video is from the African swine flu outbreak in China in 2018-19.
Label: False
html:
Claim: Pigs mulled in China are blamed for coronavirus.

Explanation:The video is from the African swine flu outbreak in China in 2018-19.

https://www.boomlive.in/fake-news/videos-of-mass-culling-of-pigs-to-stop-swine-fever-falsely-linked-to-coronavirus-6761

Claim: Four patients infected with the coronavirus are hospitalized in Sri Lanka.
Explaination: Only two suspect patients were hospitalized and both later tested negative.
Label: Misleading
html:
Claim: Four patients infected with the coronavirus are hospitalized in Sri Lanka.

Explanation:Only two suspect patients were hospitalized and both later tested negative.

https://factcheck.afp.com/sri-lankan-authorities-say-only-two-suspected-coronavirus-patients-were-hospitalised-and-both-later

Claim: Multiple posts shared repeatedly on Facebook and Twitter claim that a Hong Kong medical lab has warned the novel coronavirus can remain viable on fruits and vegetables for 12 hours, therefore people should “avoid salads” over fears of contracting COVID-19.
Explaination: The claim is false; the Centre for Food Safety in Hong Kong said there is no evidence to suggest that the virus is transmitted through food produce; the US Centers for Disease Control and Prevention (CDC) and the European Food Safety Authority (EFSA) have also separately said there is "no evidence" that COVID-19 has been transmitted through food.
Label: False
html:
Claim: Multiple posts shared repeatedly on Facebook and Twitter claim that a Hong Kong medical lab has warned the novel coronavirus can remain viable on fruits and vegetables for 12 hours, therefore people should “avoid salads” over fears of contracting COVID-19.

Explanation:The claim is false; the Centre for Food Safety in Hong Kong said there is no evidence to suggest that the virus is transmitted through food produce; the US Centers for Disease Control and Prevention (CDC) and the European Food Safety Authority (EFSA) have also separately said there is "no evidence" that COVID-19 has been transmitted through food.

https://factcheck.afp.com/hoax-circulates-online-hong-kong-covid-19-was-transmitted-through-fruits-and-vegetables

Claim: Donald Trump said about coronavirus, “People are dying who have never died before.”
Explaination: Ernest Hemingway said it.
Label: (Org. doesn't apply rating)
html:
Claim: Donald Trump said about coronavirus, “People are dying who have never died before.”

Explanation:Ernest Hemingway said it.

https://www.factcheck.org/2020/03/death-quote-wrongly-attributed-to-trump/

Claim: As per the news of Aajtak, Home Minister Amit Shah tested postive for COVID-19.
Explaination: Aajtak didn't telecast such news.
Label: False
html:
Claim: As per the news of Aajtak, Home Minister Amit Shah tested postive for COVID-19.

Explanation:Aajtak didn't telecast such news.

https://aajtak.intoday.in/story/fact-check-aajtak-never-shows-amit-shah-suffering-with-corona-virus-1-1175196.html

Claim: Boil weed and ginger for COVID-19 victims, and the virus will vanish.
Explaination: There is no evidence supporting the claim that marijuana and ginger can cure COVID-19. To date, there is no specific treatment available for COVID-19, although clinical trials evaluating certain existing drugs are underway.
Label: False
html:
Claim: Boil weed and ginger for COVID-19 victims, and the virus will vanish.

Explanation:There is no evidence supporting the claim that marijuana and ginger can cure COVID-19. To date, there is no specific treatment available for COVID-19, although clinical trials evaluating certain existing drugs are underway.

https://healthfeedback.org/claimreview/no-marijuana-and-ginger-have-not-been-shown-to-cure-covid-19/

Claim: “During the 2009 swine flu outbreak, Biden made reckless comments unsupported by science & the experts. The Obama Admin had to clean up his mess & apologize for his ineptitude.”
Explaination: During the 2009 swine flu outbreak, Biden said he would advise his family against traveling in confined places and said when one person sneezes “it goes all the way through an aircraft.” Scientists say that’s not how germs spread. Biden’s comments were met with backlash and his spokesperson issued a clarification.
Label: MOSTLY TRUE
html:
Claim: “During the 2009 swine flu outbreak, Biden made reckless comments unsupported by science & the experts. The Obama Admin had to clean up his mess & apologize for his ineptitude.”

Explanation:During the 2009 swine flu outbreak, Biden said he would advise his family against traveling in confined places and said when one person sneezes “it goes all the way through an aircraft.” Scientists say that’s not how germs spread. Biden’s comments were met with backlash and his spokesperson issued a clarification.

https://www.politifact.com/factchecks/2020/mar/13/donald-trump/fact-checking-trump-campaign-claim-bidens-2009-swi/

Claim: Post says two patients at Valley Regional Medical Center in Brownsville, Texas, “are being looked at” for possible coronavirus infections.
Explaination: Health officials say there are no coronavirus patients in the Rio Grande Valley as of March 3, 2020.
Label: False
html:
Claim: Post says two patients at Valley Regional Medical Center in Brownsville, Texas, “are being looked at” for possible coronavirus infections.

Explanation:Health officials say there are no coronavirus patients in the Rio Grande Valley as of March 3, 2020.

https://www.politifact.com/factchecks/2020/mar/03/viral-image/no-brownsville-texas-hospital-isnt-treating-two-co/

Claim: A map shows hundreds of thousands of Wuhan residents (or even 5 million of them) traveling out of the city before the lockdown.
Explaination: The map is merely “an illustrative picture of the global air network” that shows international flight connections.
Label: Misleading
html:
Claim: A map shows hundreds of thousands of Wuhan residents (or even 5 million of them) traveling out of the city before the lockdown.

Explanation:The map is merely “an illustrative picture of the global air network” that shows international flight connections.

https://medium.com/annie-lab/misleading-this-map-does-not-show-5-million-wuhan-residents-flying-out-before-the-lockdown-1e7a4ed8d9cd

Claim: Coronavirus discovered In broiler chicken.
Explaination: Unrelated images of ailing chicken shared with the claim that coronavirus has been discovered in broilers chicken. The viral post is fake.
Label: False
html:
Claim: Coronavirus discovered In broiler chicken.

Explanation:Unrelated images of ailing chicken shared with the claim that coronavirus has been discovered in broilers chicken. The viral post is fake.

https://www.vishvasnews.com/english/health/fact-check-post-claiming-coronavirus-discovered-in-broilers-chicken-in-recent-outbreak-is-fake/

Claim: Riots in London due to the unavailability of food items. The United Kingdom will be locked down by tonight. Army soldiers take to the UK streets.
Explaination: The video is not related to coronavirus but with London riots that happened in 2011. The 2011 England riots, more widely known as the London Riots, were a series of riots between 6 and 11 August 2011, when thousands of people rioted in cities and towns across England, saw looting, arson, and mass deployment of police, and resulted in the deaths of five people.
Label: False
html:
Claim: Riots in London due to the unavailability of food items. The United Kingdom will be locked down by tonight. Army soldiers take to the UK streets.

Explanation:The video is not related to coronavirus but with London riots that happened in 2011. The 2011 England riots, more widely known as the London Riots, were a series of riots between 6 and 11 August 2011, when thousands of people rioted in cities and towns across England, saw looting, arson, and mass deployment of police, and resulted in the deaths of five people.

https://www.newschecker.in/article/news-detail/275_15320709?check=5

Claim: A post says that if you hold your breath you can tell if you are infected with Covid-19 or not.
Explaination: A pulmonologist and member of the National Public Health Commission assured that this exercise doesn’t have any clinical applicability and it’s not safe. You can do the exercise, pass it and be infected with Covid-19.
Label: FALSE
html:
Claim: A post says that if you hold your breath you can tell if you are infected with Covid-19 or not.

Explanation:A pulmonologist and member of the National Public Health Commission assured that this exercise doesn’t have any clinical applicability and it’s not safe. You can do the exercise, pass it and be infected with Covid-19.

https://observador.pt/factchecks/suster-a-respiracao-e-um-teste-que-mostra-se-a-pessoa-esta-infetada-com-coronavirus/

Claim: A team of medical trainees from JKUAT (a university in Kenya) have developed and tested a vaccine successfully.
Explaination: The university that the students allegedly attended has denied the claim. Additionally, a doctor contacted by PesaCheck has indicated that a vaccine cannot be developed within a month. An Australian lab is in the initial stages of developing a vaccine by recreating the virus.
Label: False
html:
Claim: A team of medical trainees from JKUAT (a university in Kenya) have developed and tested a vaccine successfully.

Explanation:The university that the students allegedly attended has denied the claim. Additionally, a doctor contacted by PesaCheck has indicated that a vaccine cannot be developed within a month. An Australian lab is in the initial stages of developing a vaccine by recreating the virus.

https://pesacheck.org/false-a-team-of-medical-doctor-trainees-from-jkuat-has-not-produced-a-vaccine-for-coronavirus-b821354a403

Claim: Anti-malaria drug Chloroquine is a definitive cure for COVID-19.
Explaination: A study found the molecule showed 'apparent efficacy' in treating the disease, trials are still ongoing.
Label: Misleading
html:
Claim: Anti-malaria drug Chloroquine is a definitive cure for COVID-19.

Explanation:A study found the molecule showed 'apparent efficacy' in treating the disease, trials are still ongoing.

https://factcheck.afp.com/chloroquine-has-not-been-approved-treatment-covid-19

Claim: Gargling with warm water and salt or vinegar can kill coronavirus.
Explaination: An image was shared on WhatsApp claiming that gargling with warm water and salt or vinegar can kill COVID-19. There is no evidence that asserts the claims. The WHO reminds that there is still no medicine or household remedy to treat coronavirus.
Label: False
html:
Claim: Gargling with warm water and salt or vinegar can kill coronavirus.

Explanation:An image was shared on WhatsApp claiming that gargling with warm water and salt or vinegar can kill COVID-19. There is no evidence that asserts the claims. The WHO reminds that there is still no medicine or household remedy to treat coronavirus.

https://elsurti.com/coronavirus-falso-gargaras/

Claim: A “poll finds 38% of Americans say they will not drink Corona beer because of the virus.”
Explaination: The poll was conducted by a PR firm. The firm did not release full details about the poll.
Label: False
html:
Claim: A “poll finds 38% of Americans say they will not drink Corona beer because of the virus.”

Explanation:The poll was conducted by a PR firm. The firm did not release full details about the poll.

https://www.politifact.com/factchecks/2020/mar/02/facebook-posts/no-poll-does-not-say-38-americans-wont-drink-coron/

Claim: The novel coronavirus is not new.
Explaination: This is false; coronaviruses affecting cattle or canines differ from the new virus strain affecting humans, for which no vaccine exists.
Label: False
html:
Claim: The novel coronavirus is not new.

Explanation:This is false; coronaviruses affecting cattle or canines differ from the new virus strain affecting humans, for which no vaccine exists.

https://factcheck.afp.com/false-posts-claim-covid-19-existed-2019-use-animal-vaccines-proof

Claim: Army deployed in Telangana, India, amid the COVID-19 outbreak.
Explaination: Post claiming army getting deployed in Telangana amidst COVID-19 outbreak is fake. The post is refuted by the Hyderabad Police Commissioner Anjani Kumar and Indian Army.
Label: False
html:
Claim: Army deployed in Telangana, India, amid the COVID-19 outbreak.

Explanation:Post claiming army getting deployed in Telangana amidst COVID-19 outbreak is fake. The post is refuted by the Hyderabad Police Commissioner Anjani Kumar and Indian Army.

https://www.vishvasnews.com/english/health/fact-check-post-claiming-army-getting-deployed-in-telangana-amidst-covid-19-outbreak-is-fake/

Claim: 22 travelers in Uganda for the EU-Uganda Business Summit scheduled for early March had refused to go into quarantine.
Explaination: The 22 travellers had refused to go into quarantine and opted to travel back to their home countries, but they were not in Uganda for the conference as claimed.
Label: Partially false
html:
Claim: 22 travelers in Uganda for the EU-Uganda Business Summit scheduled for early March had refused to go into quarantine.

Explanation:The 22 travellers had refused to go into quarantine and opted to travel back to their home countries, but they were not in Uganda for the conference as claimed.

Claim: “There’s magically already a vaccine available.”
Explaination: Anthony S. Fauci, a top official at the National Institutes of Health (NIH), told Bloomberg Law that a potential vaccine "could move into early-stage human testing in the next three months."
Label: Not true
html:
